timeline.message:
First version of WithSpan annotation.

This should be followed by the corresponding PR in auto-instrumentation to actually create spans around annotated methods.

timeline.bodyText: Wondering if we could add an example here, so users know what kind of names could be created.

replies.bodyText: I decided not to do this on purpose. Not sure if it is a good idea to document here inner implementation details of auto-instr which may change in the future.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: Overall I'd like to see a super basic example of what names might be used. Otherwise, as a new user, I have zero idea of what name will appear.
replies.author: carlosalberto

replies.bodyText: I think things like this is why I was hesitant to put this into the API in the first place. We could provide examples all day long in the javadoc on this annotation, but who knows what will actually be done by the auto-instrumentation agent, or some other annotation processor? I feel like putting examples in here could just confuse people even more when the actual span names end up looking different.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText:
@jkwatson Agreed but mentioning that X or Y name might be chosen would be a fine thing to mention (without giving away too many details). In that regard, a basic, single example of what it could look like would be more than enough.
So to not wait forever to have this PR merged, lets go ahead with what we have now @iNikem and maybe update the docs later on with a single, simple example.
replies.author: carlosalberto

replies.bodyText: An interesting question is whether we would have another package for common, non-auto-related annotations potentially (in the future, that is).
replies.author: carlosalberto

replies.bodyText:
Based on my understanding this annotation will not be able to work without some kind of bytecode manipulation. So it is important to call that for the users and let them know that this should not be used if they are not sure if the final application will use byte-code manipulation.
In the same notes probably third-party integrations should not use this.
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: I have added this notice in javadoc. Please review.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: @bogdandrutu Fair enough, lets take this route.
